newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait MPs blast government on death attempt on MP.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait MPs blast government on death attempt on MP.

text.p: Kuwaiti parliamentarians sharply criticised the government on Saturday after a leading liberal opposition MP was wounded in an assassination attempt.
The government urged MPs not to foment internal strife after Oxford-educated Abdullah al-Naibari, 61, was shot twice on Friday evening. His wife was also wounded in the ambush.

Gunmen ambushed Naibari's car as he drove to Kuwait City from a beach near the southern border with Saudi Arabia. He was hit in the jaw and shoulder and his wife suffered a superficial bullet wound near her left shoulder. On Saturday government officials said both were in good condition in hospital.
Naibari has played a key role in efforts to combat alleged corruption since parliament was restored in 1992 and he often questions lucrative arms deals.
At the end of a tense debate on Saturday parliament said in a statement the attack was an attempt "...to scare decision makers from defending rightfulness and legitimacy".

The tiny Gulf Arab state's acting premier and foreign minister, Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, told MPs: "Please do not pour petrol on the fire. Starting a fire would not only harm us but will harm the whole of Kuwait."
Some MPs claimed that government failure to strike hard against former officials who allegedly mismanaged and squandered public funds had led to the attack against Naibari.
"The country is in real danger...These people are not without allies. They will continue on this path unless there is a clear position," speaker Ahmad al-Saadoun told parliament.
MP Ahmad al-Mulaifi said: "This case (attack) is an extension of other cases that we failed to deal with. Judges, ministers and undersecretaries could be the next targets."
There are several cases before the courts of alleged illegal profits by former officials, including some involving operations at the state-owned Kuwait Oil Tanker Company (KOTC).
The government has strongly condemned the attack against Naibari and promised an intensive investigation to secure the swift arrest of the unidentified gunmen.
Diplomats said Western embassies were assessing the security situation but did not expect visits to Kuwait this month by U.S. and British ministers to be postponed.
